The Culling of the Cows is an absurdist gag game that, while it may provide you with all the rampant bovine slaughter you could ever dream of, is as of now not at all worth the price paid for it.As a lone farmer stranded in rural 'Murica, you must overcome the armies of mutant cows, deranged hippies and obese gothic women that a Nazi UFO sends your way. By reading the previous sentence, it should be quite clear that this game is not taking itself too seriously. However, there is a clear difference between random humor with a purpose and random just for random's sake; this game strictly falls into the latter. Culling is basing its appeal entirely on the fact that the player gets to shoot cows...a lot. All of the other plot points mentioned in the beginning of this paragraph receive no explanation besides a single introduction screen per plot point, and are otherwise meant to serve as comedic masks for generic enemy types.The game's fundamentals are disappointingly lacking. Gameplay is divided into levels that contain encounters in either standard "Waves" format, a variation of Waves that is only one large wave, or a last-stand turret mode called "Onslaught". The majority of the game's levels occur in the Waves format, with varying numbers and types of enemies and waves for each level. This variety does little to put off the repetition that sets in after a few rounds of slaughtering the same few animals and zombies over and over. The Waves format does allow for some character customization in weapon upgrades, but after a certain amount of experimentation I discovered an order of upgrades that, with moderate skill, could win all the levels. Some incentive in the level design to switch up gameplay styles would have gone a long way. The other gameplay mode, Onslaught, produces some of the most frustrating levels in the game due to sketchy hit detection, though it often provides a refreshing and enjoyable break from the Waves levels as well.Various other parts of the game fail to stand out. The soundtrack isn't memorable and the art style has this feel to it that so many indie games seem to have, which at worst could be descibed as "one step above MS Paint". Largely, the game isn't bad-looking; it just has a habit of piling hundreds of multicolored cow corpses on the screen at once, which grates on the senses and leaves a lasting impact after seeing it over and over. Some parts of the game seem to be implemented strangely: controller support, despite being labelled as both "partial" and "full", relegates movement solely to the D-Pad, which is an odd choice. Culling's achievements are also strange: there are only five, four can be attained by the third level (two are bugged to only work with the keyboard) and the fifth is for beating the game. More achievements could help boost replayability, a facet which is important in this game considering it can be finished in just over three hours. Though most levels contain medals to earn for winning under certain conditions, the game doesn't offer rewards for earning the medals, which makes them largely meaningless. Perhaps tying some customization unlocks to medals would solve this issue?Though this game faces significant issues, I must give praise to the spirit of the developers. They've implemented some features like an internal cheat console, the achievements and trading cards by popular demand. Additionally, their desire to not make this game be simply a joke shows throughout the game. The farmer's voiceover has some genuinely unique and funny lines interspersed throughout the game, which work because the lines are not beaten to death in every level. As long as the developers stand by the good-hearted cow hate that is the root of this game, there's hope that this could turn into an indie cult classic in the future.This game has set off on a mission: to spread the need to shoot cows whenever, wherever. It tries to achieve its goals through a game that has significant flaws. Should the developers focus on the problems that plague the core elements of the game, then this title will definitely deserve a second look. As of now, however, there is no way anyone would feel satisfied paying full price for this game. Save up for a sale, perhaps gift this to a friend in jest. Just...beware the cows. The Culling of the Cows gets a D.

												The Culling Of The Cows is a side-scrolling shooter. You are Sammy, a farmer, and you have to defend your properties with your shotgun against waves and waves of cows, zombies and undead cows.There are lots of levels in this game. The classic type of level involves defending your farm against successive waves of ennemies. You will also play some levels where there is only one wave, but a big one ! Not to forget the last kind of level, which is a level where you are in your farmhouse, shooting ennemies from the window with infinite ammos !For the first two types of levels, you can :- Upgrade your ammos. 4 different types of ammos are available : the normal ones, the "spreading" ones, the "piercing" ones and the "explosives" one. You just have to buy the type of ammos, then you have access to an infinite amount of them.- Upgrade your weapon. The first option is to increase the amount of ammos you have in your shotgun. The second one is to increase the number of bullets you put in your weapon each time you reload it (the most useful to my mind). The third one allows you to decrease the delay between each of your shot. The last one gives you an horizontal red line to make it easier to aim.- Use Assists. These are special powers that will greatly help you. You can have access up to 4 of them, depending on the level. They can be used freely, you will just have to wait a little bit between each use. For instance, you can spawn an helicopter that will destroy ennemies with a machine-gun, or ignite a fire that will burn any ennemies that will walk (or at least try) through it.- Use Supplies. Just using a specific key, you can spawn supplies which will grant you money or a bonus for a short period of time (invicibility, infinite ammos, speed increase, time slowed down, ...).For each of these levels, you can get 3 "medals" (it looks like achievements for each level, but they are only in-game, not Steam). To unlock that, you will have to complete a level without upgrading your ammos, upgrading your weapon, using Assists ... You do not need to unlock all three of them at the same time, you can focus on a specific one and complete the level again focusing on an other one.Regarding the ennemies, you will encounter different kinds of them : standard cow, charging cow, very big cow, explosive cow, standard zombie, pretty-hard-to-kill zombie, etc ... Also, beware the crows falling from the sky, they are indicated with a blue beam, so that you have time to avoid them ! And, of course, there is a final stage with a final boss, which is not that difficult to defeat.In the end, The Culling Of The Cows is a fine game, I had a lot of fun playing it even though it is kind of repetitive after the first levels and the gameplay is mainly based on "when to reload your weapon". It took me ~5-6 hours to get all of the medals and defeat the final boss. This will unlock all of the Steam achievements. The soundtrack fits well with the game and the graphics are fine. I played with a gamepad, I think it is much more enjoyable than using a keyboard.More content would be great because, once you have killed the final boss + got all of the medals, there is nothing more you can do. And, for more than 10€, it seems expensive to have only a 6 hours-game. I would recommend to buy this game during sales or try to get it in a bundle, but do not spend the full amount for it :-)

 The Culling of the Cows ReviewSo one day, I visited a site that I love to go on for game info, RPS. I saw an advert for a free copy of "Culling of the Cows," so I figured I would give it a try. And I am very glad that I did. Part 1:  Storyline and Gameplay In COTC, you are a farmer who encounters everything from zombie cows to Nazi UFOs on his farm. It is your job to shoot the oncoming cattle and other enemies before they can enter your barn. There is a plethora of upgrades for your weapons, barn, and even "God Abilities." It could be considered a sidescroller (but with no scrolling), but this game will appeal to both arcade gamers and retro shoot-em-up gamers alike.As for the length of the game, COTC has an adequate number of "missions" which provide for plenty of hours of fun gameplay. And if you ever, for some odd reason, get bored of destroying zombie cows with a barn-mounted machine gun, there are cheat codes to get you to the final mission and other such objectives. Part 2: Graphics?  There isn't too much to say about the graphics here. The game could have done well as a pixel graphic game, but I believe that the developers made the right decision sticking with non-pixelated cows. You get an arcade feel from the graphics while still being able to make out sharp lines and appropriate detail. Part 3: Is it fun?  Of course it's fun! This game is unlike any other arcade-zombie-tower defense game you've played before! Imagine Farming Simulator, but instead of growing crops, you shoot cows, and instead of upgrading your equipment, you upgrade your explosive-bullet extended mag infinite ammo no reload shotgun! This is a game that you can definitely lose track of time while playing and get caught up in the hilarity and epicness of the goals. Value As I said before, I got this game as part of a special promotion, however, I would gladly have bought this game. It's well worth the money (At time of writing: $1.94, 85% off)! Let's put it this way - you can get a pack of gum or two which might last just a few days, or you can get COTC and have dozens of fun hours of gameplay! The only thing is that I feel like $12.99 is a little bit much to ask for regular price, I would wait for it to go on sale. Definitely a game that you can casually pick up right where you left off, even if it's been a week or two. Would recommend.  Aspect Rating   Gameplay 9   Graphics 8   Enjoyability 10   Value 7  Final Points on the Game This game is a definite buy, whether it's 2 bucks or 10. You'll have a great time playing it, and best of all, it has zombies with  no early access ! What's not to love about that!Be sure to check out any of my other reviews on my profile, and please upvote if this helped you, I hope it did! Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												   The Culling of the Cows stands between Plants Versus Zombies (Or old farmer vs zombie cows -- and possibly nazi aliens) and a sidescrolling shooter.   This is made by Decaying Logic, the same developers that brought us Radical Roach, which I reviewed a while ago (and was not impressed at all).   While I believe this is definitely an improvement over Radical Roach, many of the same flaws and design choices are present in this game, just to a lesser extent.    As usual, I'll start with presentation.   Not unlike their previous game, the Artstyle is probably one of the defining points. While it feels like flash, the animations are pretty good, although a bit too limited (there is only one animation for each enemy, it seems, as well as the carcass sprite, which makes the field end up looking a bit too monotonous).    The interface templates don't really seem to fit the theme, but it's not too bad. Other visuals effects are also subpar, against the cartoony style they were mostly going for.   There are a few different areas that slightly change the look of the map, but don't be fooled, as the map doesn't change at all, except for the visuals.   One problem I've had with it, is that the dead bodies cover up the screen by the end of the levels, to the point that you can't see new enemies arrive very clearly. That should definitely be changed. Other than that, it's fine.   The Music is also very similar to Radical Roach. It's not awful, and it has some good moments, but it's very repetitive, and doesn't loop very well, which is unfortunate. It's upbeat, and a mixture between some rock/metal and electronic music which goes for the more arcade vibe than atmosphere. There are some old sci-fi melodies though, which is a nice addition.    One improvement that I want to stress is that the music no longer restarts whenever you fail a level! It's a weird aspect to consider, but I think it's very important. It didn't happen in RR, and it was really annoying to listen the song start over and over again. Now, it doesn't happen, and it's a subtle but important improvement, in my opinion!   So, let's talk about the Mechanics.   As I said, it's has a bit of PvZ in it. Essentially, you have a large lane to defend agains the zombies. There are no specific lanes as in PvZ, you can freely walk around, and so can the enemies. You have a shotgun, different ammo types, upgrades, and assists. You'll also, periodically, be able to call for a crate with a random power-up.   Your job is to stop zombies from entering the barn, and also avoid being killed by them (if they hit you). Pretty straightforward.   You have a world map with the levels spread around (unlocking more as you go) with a couple of spreading paths, somewhat like One Finger Death Punch, only much smaller. These levels include a few different modes. There's Waves, in which, well, you fight waves of enemies, and there's a limit number of zombies that can enter the barn; Kill 'Em All, in which there's only one long wave and you can't let any zombie pass; Onslaught, in whichsome zombies can go through, but you have a machine gun (or a bazooka in one level) and shoot from the top of the barn, not worrying about dodging. And then, there's a couple of Boss levels.   The first two play essentially the same, with the exception that you can a few seconds to "rest" between waves. It had very, very little to the overall experience, but hey.   There's a significant number of different enemies, although a bunch of them are just faster or healthier versions of the previous. Still, it keeps the game interesting when starting out, since you need to change up your play a bit. Later on, new enemies stop coming, and every level becomes waay too similar (which is a feat in a 3 hour game).   There are also 3 badges to unlock in most levels -- these make the game harder, but they're barely there to reward you. There are some not to let any zombies pass, or not to miss any shot, but the others are simply about not upgrading your weapon, not using assists, etc. These do NOT make the game more fun at all. On the contrary, you're just shooting yourselves on the foot by limiting variety. It would certainly add challenge, but it's not very interesting challenge, in my opinion. But they're all optional, so it's fine. If you're into that, it exists. Overall, I'd say rethink your design on that.   Weapon upgrades are only on a level to level basis, and not persistent. You can increase the number of bullets, the number of bullets you reload at a time, add a laser to increase accuracy, or do something else that I'm not entirely sure of. I assumed it's reload speed.    Regarding ammo, you have Spread Shot, Explosive Shot, and Penetrating Shot. These do not stack, much to my disappointment. It could be really fun to have Spread Explosive Shots and just explode everything! But no... there are no synergies. If you purchase both, they'll alternate between them, from what I could tell.   Assists go from a chainsaw in the barn entrance to an AirStrike, or an Auto Machine Gun, for a few seconds. There are more to these, and they have a cooldown associated. I didn't use any of them, most of the time, because they weren't needed, nor particularly fun to use. You just press the button, and have the game made easier... But it's good that it's there, there's certainly room for different playstyles! Maybe you'd prefer not to upgrade your weapon as much, and focus on "traps", that's totally fine!   Ammo and Upgrades in-game cost money. And here's the big issue I have with it: You start each level with a certain amount. Then, by calling the random power-up, there's a chance you'll get a bit more, but it's generally not significant. So, you'll mostly upgrade your weapon at the start of the level, and then play with that. It's not dynamic at all, as every level played out pretty much the same to me. Sure, I could have forced myself to use different "loadouts", but the one I had worked for me, and the enemies didn't really require different tactics to be beaten. It would have been better to gain money over time, having waves get progressively more difficult, scaling with the upgrades you were able to buy!   Pacing is pretty much unexistant, unfortunately.   Well, maybe I'm being a bit too negative. The fact of the matter is that the game didn't do anything interesting to me. However, it was still somewhat fun for a bit. The kind of mindless fun you need to just pass time. You'll fight dozens of enemies per level, making each field become just a bunch of bloody cows on the ground. It's dumb, but it's somewhat enjoyable. Just not very interesting... Take One Finger Death Punch, for instance. That game is totally mindless fun! But it's far more interesting. First, it's very rhythmical, and you need to be in the "zone" to identify which enemies require which clicks to perfectly complete a level. And there are many different weapon that actually *feel* different, and make you look like a badass, cutting everyone up. I realize that these are two different games, but they both go for a similar feeling, that's why I'm bringing it up.   One aspect I enjoyed quite a lot was the last Boss. That was a pretty fun fight. Even though it had no upgrades or anything, the 3 phases complemented each other pretty well, and while challenging, it didn't feel frustrating to me. It should have had a few more boss fights, would definitely make the game more interesting.That's enough rambling. For the price, I can't recommend it at all. But if this seems appealing to you, give it a shot if the price drops. While I've beaten it in 3 hours, you can get a bit more out of it, if you go for the badges. And the developers seem to update the game from time to time, so it may get better. Overall, not awful, but not particularly good either.

Posted: December 10, 2014
												The Culling Of The Cows is a short game, in which you play as a farmer during a zombie apocalypse, only that, instead of human zombies (well, there are some of them), there are cow zombies. Armed only with a shotgun, you must defend your barn from these zombies.Even though you have a single weapon through most of the game (the aforementioned shotgun), there's two extra weapons that appear in specific levels: a machine gun, and a rocket launcher. Even then, the shotgun can use four different types of ammo, and there's several upgrades for it, that make it even better at killing stuff. You can also get supply drops (like extra cash for upgrading your weapon, invincibility, etc), and use different abilities to kill the zombies, like providing your barn with a machine gun, or a saw, sending a nuke, etc.Even though the idea of shooting cows might sound dull at first, there's a good variety of enemies: different types of cows (even cows strapped with TNT, helpful for blowing up nearby cows!), and, as already mentioned, a few human enemies. There's also crows falling from the sky.As far as gameplay goes, all the levels consist of you defending your barn against waves of enemies (or against a single, large wave), with a few changes: in most of the levels, you're in front of your barn, and the cows can kill you, while in a few "Onslaught" levels, you shoot the cows from the safety of your barn's second floor.Nice game, once you get the hang of it. I recommend it.

												For a silly shooter defense type game where you defend your farm from cows and what not... I'd say this is a game worth playing.Many things were enjoyable such as the following:Positives:♦ Almost Each level is unique ♦ Every level you beat unlocks new enemies ♦ Every level you beat unlocks new support items♦ Unique way to upgrade weapons♦ Breaks between waves♦ Random Events in the form of a deployable Crate♦ Hilarious story and voice overs♦ Achievements for playing the game basicallyNow don't get me wrong there are many positives, but still not every game is perfect and this one has the following negative points:Negatives:♦ Accuracy of the shots are slightly off♦ Cheats which can be used to get the achievements♦ Waves per level are way too long♦ Can get repetitive quite quickly♦ Little overpriced as I got mine in a bundle and Indiegala gave it away freeImprovements:♦ Fix the Accuracy♦ Make Cheats only usable once finished the game♦ Lower Waves per round (So it feels less repetitive)Overall, in my opinion, the game is hillarious, fun and worth playing despite the accuracy of shots being slightly off and the slight repetitiveness. Though if you don't use cheats, enjoy easy to get achievements and love a laugh whilst playing a video game, then I highly recommend this for you.Overall, I'd rate this 3.5/5!PS: If you try and get all the stars for every level in the game, you'll be there for a while making this game have very godo replay value!

The Last Stand is a free Flash game, and it's much better than this, because it avoided Cows' glaring design flaws.The biggest problem is that you can't aim your shotgun freely - it's always pointed straight across the screen, like in an old arcade game. Even though you are clearly firing a spread of pellets from your shotgun, you have to be very careful that you're not too high or too low to hit the stampeding cow (all of which KILL YOU IN ONE HIT). Again, I'm used to this kind of system from old arcade games, but it feels unfair in this game, especially given the way that cows will run in fast at a diagonal. There's actually a laser sight upgrade for your shotgun, but it doesn't help much.Your shotgun has a high ammo capacity (especially if you upgrade it) but you have to reload each shell manually by pressing R. (This is more annoying than it sounds).You have sentry guns and such that you can activate to kill some cows for you, but you have to activate most of them at just the right time, which is not really practical with the standard mouse+keyboard controls....What's that you say? You'll just use a controller with a nice, convenient button for each trap? Nope, sorry, but controller support is AWFUL. You can only move around with the directional pad (the sticks do nothing!), and there are no dedicated buttons for the traps and upgrades. (The game actually tells you "Controllers are for♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" when you select it in the options menu. That's the quite the excuse for terrible support...)Also, the levels end up covered in so many cow corpses that it becomes difficult to tell which still need shooting (some of the basic enemies stop moving for a second or two, which ends up faking you out) and of course having to climb over dozens of their fallen cow-sisters doesn't slow them down at all.

												It's surprisingly fun, Culling of the Cows. Barn on the left, Zombies come from the right, kill them before they get to the barn. Survive multiple waves to beat the level, but be careful, since if the Zombies touch/hit you, you will die instantly. To compare it to another game, its a lot like the "The Last Stand" Flash game, and I'm talking about the first 'The Last Stand'. Also one of the more difficult parts about shooting is that you can only shoot strait ahead of your character, as in you can't use the mouse to angle his gun to the upper/lower rows.Other than the basic shooting, with your Shotgun, there are 4 other aspects in fighting. Ammo - There are 4 ammo types: Normal, Buckshot, Piercing, and Explosive. You need to pay for these. Supply Drop - When you press the Supply Drop button, a crate will fall from the air, a delivery strait from God(seriously). It can contain various temporary powerups like 10 second invincibility, Unlimited Ammo(10sec), or even basic Cash Drops. When a Drop is called, the ability is placed on cooldown, and can be pressed again when it goes off the cooldown. This is free to use. Assists - This is where God himself, I'm serious here, helps you out. Like placing a giant saw in front of your barn door to kill advancing zombies, or a turret that randomly shoots, or a wall of fire in the middle of the screen. They are brief, like 10 seconds or something, and go on a cooldown after used, but they're useful. These are Free to use. Upgrades - These are 4 simple upgrades for your Shotgun, they are: Clip Size, Reload Speed, Shoot Speed, and a Laser Pointer. You need to pay for these.Each level you start out with a certain amount of cash. These can be used on the Ammo or Upgrades. You can get more cash from Supply Drops. The higher the level, the more you start with. And for the record, Ammo and Upgrades to not transfer to other levels.I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed The Last Stand, or anyone who likes this type of game.

												 As many of us are aware, the "indie developer" scene is exploding as of late when it comes to game creation. With so many independent companies trying to stake their claim in the gaming world, it's tough to keep track of games that are truly worthy of attention, versus those that are... well... just white noise. Among these developers is a company by the name of Decaying Logic, and they have created a unique take on the sidescrolling shooter with "Culling of the Cows."     "Culling of the Cows" is game that is based around, you guessed, killing hordes of livestock that seem to have been infected or otherwise possessed by some strange force. Rather than feeding on hay or grass like their "more alive" brethren, the cattle of CotC prefer the taste of meat. Thankfully though, "God" and his newly appointed tool of destruction, Sammy, have something else in mind: to eliminate the existence of these flesh-craving, ravenous bovine zombie hordes. The entire game revolves entirely around this idea and it is very well executed in doing so.     Through each level, the player is given the option to choose between several different types of ammo that range from the typical 12 gauge buckshot, all the way up to exploding rounds. These ammo types can be purchased with the in-game credits that are given to Sammy at the beginning of each level. Not only does Sammy old boy get credits at the start of each stage, but he also has the chance to earn more by supply drops. Supply drops give the player a random chance to get certain temporary upgrades, such as the aforementioned credits as well as ammo reloads or speed boosts just to name a few. On top of these supply drops (if the level permits) Sammy can call upon God to rain down various "miracles" which, in all honesty, is pretty much a full military arsenal to rain down death upon the infected livestock. The fun doesn't stop there though!     Aside from all of the neat little upgrades and quirky buffs given to the player, there is also quite the selection of enemies. Some easy to kill like the typical black cow, while others... well... they need a little more "convincing" in order to admit defeat at the hands of our hillbilly protagonist. The levels are numerous and the entertainment value can be described as somewhat worthy. At times, the game will seem to get redundant, but it's definitely a must-have if you are in the mood for getting your hands dirty with a little mindless arcade "shoot to kill" action.     As far as true replay value goes, there might be some to be considered. Given the short nature of the game, speed runs can most definitely be considered. Or... if you wanna try your hand at a perfect run on every level, that is most certainly an option as well!   Overall, Culling of the Cows makes its unique mark on the Indie Dev world and although it is rather short in gameplay length, the features that are included make it well worth the price. 												This is a typical wave based 2D shoot em up. It has a funny little gimmic which is basically a nazi ufo turns the cows into zombies. So it's not that serious.  Graphics:  The art style is okay, nothing special. Looks like a flash game. Sound:  The enemies have good sounds (except that annoying crow) just like the weapons. I think the voice over work is rly cheesy sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't. The music is repetitive as hell you won't stand it longer than like 2,3 levels. The problem is basically there is a 30 sec loop and nothing else except for the menu music.  Gameplay:  You have to shoot down cows and other enemies in front of you. There are many types of enemies like super fast cow, tank cow, a crazy cow that comes at you in a crisscross and many more. So the enemy variety is good. But the algorithm is easy: Is this guy ahead of the others? -> shoot OR is this guy faster than the others? -> shoot that first.There are game modes like simple turret sectons, boss fights, 1 big wave, normal wave. You can upgrade your shotgun in the previous 2. There are ammo types like birdshot, buckshot, slug... each is different but I think the buckshot is your bread and butter because it shoots in a cone. And the awkward hit detection (or the sense of position I'm not sure) is really annoying and it puts you out of the mood. You can also upgrade your ammo capacity, reload speed, fire rate, and you can attach a laser pointer on your shotgun. These upgrades can be obtained by your starter and drop money. You can also call for a care packege which contains money or powerups like unlimited ammo, unlimited health, slomo... for a limited time. But I walked through them almost every time because of the awkward sense of position.You can also call aids like air strike, napalm barrels, nuke and other over the top stuff. The game gets really repetitive after 30-60 minutes. There is only one level type (The Farm) but it indicates like there will be other themes but no... just the farm.  Replayability:  There are achievements per stage but you mustn't use the upgrade system or the aid system to earn these which defeats the only good thing in the game. Overall:   Pros:   Setting Nice upgrade system and air support bonuses Gore Trading Cards Casual fun time for a few hours  Cons:   Only 1 weapon (except for the turret segments) Annoying hit detection and sense of position Music is bad and repetitive Lack of variety in levels Questionable game design The Extras menu leads you to nowhere... HIgh price! Verdict:  It's not worth 11 euros for sure. If you want some mindless fun for a few hours then buy it on a sale. I had some fun but I had many many frustrated moments as well. It's an average game at best. Won't kill you but won't save you. My recomendation is neutral but the actual price lowers it a little bit. Oh and if you want to play it the "fun" way it lasts 2 hours.

Thankfully though, "God" and his newly appointed tool of destruction, Sammy, have something else in mind: to eliminate the existence of these flesh-craving, ravenous bovine zombie hordes. The entire game revolves entirely around this idea and it is very well executed in doing so.     Through each level, the player is given the option to choose between several different types of ammo that range from the typical 12 gauge buckshot, all the way up to exploding rounds. These ammo types can be purchased with the in-game credits that are given to Sammy at the beginning of each level. Not only does Sammy old boy get credits at the start of each stage, but he also has the chance to earn more by supply drops. Supply drops give the player a random chance to get certain temporary upgrades, such as the aforementioned credits as well as ammo reloads or speed boosts just to name a few. On top of these supply drops (if the level permits) Sammy can call upon God to rain down various "miracles" which, in all honesty, is pretty much a full military arsenal to rain down death upon the infected livestock. The fun doesn't stop there though!     Aside from all of the neat little upgrades and quirky buffs given to the player, there is also quite the selection of enemies. Some easy to kill like the typical black cow, while others... well... they need a little more "convincing" in order to admit defeat at the hands of our hillbilly protagonist. The levels are numerous and the entertainment value can be described as somewhat worthy. At times, the game will seem to get redundant, but it's definitely a must-have if you are in the mood for getting your hands dirty with a little mindless arcade "shoot to kill" action.     As far as true replay value goes, there might be some to be considered. Given the short nature of the game, speed runs can most definitely be considered. Or... if you wanna try your hand at a perfect run on every level, that is most certainly an option as well!   Overall, Culling of the Cows makes its unique mark on the Indie Dev world and although it is rather short in gameplay length, the features that are included make it well worth the price. Whether you are looking for a time killer, or wanting a new "speed run" challenge to compete with friends with, or even just looking for a good challenge to achieve that perfect score, CotC definitely delivers.For more information on Culling of the Cows, or to download the game for yourself, please visit:http://decayinglogic.com/the-culling-of-the-cows/Be sure to check out my other content!YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9wBb1EsrvF6mEPTWD1d0qABlog: http://btngaminggamereviews.blogspot.com/Tumblr: http://bringthenoisegaming.tumblr.com/Follow me on Twitter: @BTN_Gaming

Introduction:  The Culling Of The Cows is a game very similar to what you would find on a free flash game website. It is a game in which you, playing as a farmer armed with a gun and various "assists", must fend off waves of enemies by moving up and down the screen, shooting in the proper "lane" the enemies are approaching from. While the game offered some mindless fun, I cannot fully recommend it as it does not do anything innovative to the genre, especially a genre that is overloaded with many other games (that are, not to mention, free).Gameplay:  As previously mentioned, many users of flash game websites will immediately find something familiar in the gameplay. Moving up and down the screen, you must kill the approaching enemies, which happen to be mostly cows, before they reach you or the barn behind you.Each level of the game gives you a number of credits to spend for that level specifically, with more credits being available through supply drops that can be used periodically during the level. These credits can be used to change the type of gun you are using as well as upgrade your gun. You start each level with a standard rifle that only fires in a straight line. You can purchase a shotgun, which fires bullets spread over several "lanes", another rifle which fires penetrating bullets, and a rifle which fires explosive bullets. For upgrades, you can improve the size of your clip, how many bullets you reload at a time, and how many bullets you fire at once. You also have the option of purchasing a laser sight for your gun. All of these upgrades are applied, even if you switch weapon types.While there are choices in weapon types and upgrades, realistically, there is not much of a choice. The credits given to you for a level - including supply drops - was never really enough to purchase multiple weapon types after purchasing the - almost required - upgrades. The shotgun is quite plainly the best weapon in the game with little point of using anything else; the ability to attack multiple lanes at once is extremely invaluable and many of the enemies that take more than one bullet to kill are all killed by one shotgun attack anyway. The only upgrades that are needed are clip size upgrades and how many bullets are reloaded at once. The laser sight is essentially useless once the player gets used to the game, and increasing the number of bullets fired at a time does not really affect anything even if not using the shotgun.An important aspect of this genre of game is the enemy types. While there is enemy variety, your gameplay style does not need to change as a result to this. It would have been interesting if a different gun type was needed for certain enemies; however, this is not the case here. Every enemy approaches in a straight line apart from one and, as mentioned before, a shotgun will kill every enemy in one hit regardless. While the game does promote "strategic value", it quickly becomes mindless, especially as the waves get longer and longer.Besides your gun, you also have access to assists. These assists are provided free of credits and gated only by a cooldown, with different ones being provided for each level. Nearly every assist is simply a screen clear, in a "get out of jail free" way. I personally felt this made the game far too easy, and only used them on a handful of occasions. To put it in comparison, the later levels give you five different assists to use, each with their own cooldown. With each of these assists clearing the screen on their own...it is highly overpowered, to the point where the player no longer needs to fire their weapon at all.Most of the levels of the game follow this format. There are "Onslaught" levels, which places the player in a barn and gives them infinite ammo and "Kill 'Em All" levels, which have one big wave opposed to several small waves. There are two boss levels, which play very similarly to the standard levels.Art & Graphics:  Shown by the screenshots, the game looks very similar to a flash game. The graphics are a bit more polished, however it is nothing special. As the playing field gets completely covered with the bodies of the zombies, it becomes more and more difficult to appreciate the graphics that do exist.Sound:  There is only one music track in the game from what I heard, and it repeats very quickly. The death sound for each enemy is always the same - the black cows always make the same sound, the green cows always make the same sound, etc. With the sheer number of enemies later on, the game quickly becomes a mess of these sounds. Even on a very low volume, I was still annoyed by this mess of sound.Replay Value:  The game took nearly three hours to complete all 40 levels. As part of a free update, each level has three "challenges" to complete which are revealed upon beating the level the first time. These challenges include letting no zombie into the barn behind you, not upgrading your weapon, not using assists, and not missing a shot. There are Steam achievements for the game; however these are all earned by naturally completing the game.Prismatic Complaints:  There is an "Extras" option on the menu that does not work. The player must press the reload button for every time they wish to reload. While most of the enemies in the game are cows, there are four non-cow enemies, slightly ruining the theme of the game.Closing:  While I do find the idea of zombie cows amusing, and the death animations for the player had me laughing, I cannot recommend this game when there are many other games that do it better while also being free.

												 As many of us are aware, the "indie developer" scene is exploding as of late when it comes to game creation. With so many independent companies trying to stake their claim in the gaming world, it's tough to keep track of games that are truly worthy of attention, versus those that are... well... just white noise. Among these developers is a company by the name of Decaying Logic, and they have created a unique take on the sidescrolling shooter with "Culling of the Cows."     "Culling of the Cows" is game that is based around, you guessed, killing hordes of livestock that seem to have been infected or otherwise possessed by some strange force. Rather than feeding on hay or grass like their "more alive" brethren, the cattle of CotC prefer the taste of meat. Thankfully though, "God" and his newly appointed tool of destruction, Sammy, have something else in mind: to eliminate the existence of these flesh-craving, ravenous bovine zombie hordes. The entire game revolves entirely around this idea and it is very well executed in doing so.     Through each level, the player is given the option to choose between several different types of ammo that range from the typical 12 gauge buckshot, all the way up to exploding rounds. These ammo types can be purchased with the in-game credits that are given to Sammy at the beginning of each level. Not only does Sammy old boy get credits at the start of each stage, but he also has the chance to earn more by supply drops. Supply drops give the player a random chance to get certain temporary upgrades, such as the aforementioned credits as well as ammo reloads or speed boosts just to name a few. On top of these supply drops (if the level permits) Sammy can call upon God to rain down various "miracles" which, in all honesty, is pretty much a full military arsenal to rain down death upon the infected livestock. The fun doesn't stop there though!     Aside from all of the neat little upgrades and quirky buffs given to the player, there is also quite the selection of enemies. Some easy to kill like the typical black cow, while others... well... they need a little more "convincing" in order to admit defeat at the hands of our hillbilly protagonist. The levels are numerous and the entertainment value can be described as somewhat worthy. At times, the game will seem to get redundant, but it's definitely a must-have if you are in the mood for getting your hands dirty with a little mindless arcade "shoot to kill" action.     As far as true replay value goes, there might be some to be considered. Given the short nature of the game, speed runs can most definitely be considered. Or... if you wanna try your hand at a perfect run on every level, that is most certainly an option as well!   Overall, Culling of the Cows makes its unique mark on the Indie Dev world and although it is rather short in gameplay length, the features that are included make it well worth the price. 												TL;DR: Simple fast-paced, albeit short, wave defender. I'd advice to get it on discount.In Culling of the Cows you slaughter hundreds of cows, a couple of badgers and also some hipsters. All of them are zombies though. There's a reason for that revealed at the end but it's totally ridiculous like the whole idea itself. For whatever reason you don't want the monsters in your barn. You got to go through the farm utterly destroying all the undead bovine life forms with your trusty shotgun and (!) the muda♥♥♥♥ing airforces.Perhaps surprisingly, this is rather fun and enjoyable. Voice acting is horrible though but for that matter the game lasts only couple of hours even if you try to ace everything.Every level you begin with a shotgun shooting slugs. God promises to sell you better weapons and help along the way because he's a such good guy. He also sends you money to pay for all the stuff. Then you proceed to kill all the enemies rampaging towards you. You got to reload manually so proceed with care and precision. This can be annoying as the hitboxes are quite small. This also makes the spread-out ammo upgrade super useful.Frankly, you can only shoot forward and you're slow at walking, so sometimes you can't prevent a cow from passing or indeed killing you. This is where assists come in: you can call up airforces, bombings, sentry guns, fire walls, all kinds of overpowered defenses that will mostly take care of your job for you, with brief cooldowns in between. Still it often takes another try to ace any level, especially since that means you can't buy some overpowered weapons.It wouldn't stay fresh for long but fortunately it's also quite short, the 40 levels taking only some 2-3 hours to ace. However, the short length is also a curse: it's not really worth the full price. However, at a decent discount or in a bundle, go for it.
